§6§lThe nanofluidics can explain ascent of water in tallest trees§r

§8§oHenri Gouin§r

§72012§r

Comments: \u00a77\u00a7oMethods. We compare two experiments: - The Scholander pressure bomb experiment (1955)based on the cohesion-tension theory (1894) in which liquids are considered to be incompressible. - The Sheludko experiment (1967)

based on the concept of disjoining pressure in DLVO theory (1948) that highlights a strongdifference between liquid bulk and thin layer pressures. The theoretical results allow us to obtain: - The computation of tallest trees' level

that fits with real facts - The interpretation of the motion in xylem microtubes by using theshallow water approximation and the slippage on walls at the nanometric scale. arXivadmin note: text overlapwith arXiv:1106.1275\u00a7r
